title: 111_hr4250
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The Act is titled the "Medicaid DSH Integrity Act" and highlights the importance of Medicaid DSH payments for safety net hospitals serving the poor and uninsured. Reporting and auditing requirements added in 2003 aim to ensure proper use of DSH funds. The Department of Health and Human Services and States are ensuring that DSH funds are used for their intended purpose of assisting hospitals serving low-income individuals. Changes to Medicaid DSH policy have narrowed the scope of payments for many States. The DSH policy changes are narrowing the scope of payments for many States, resulting in reductions of millions of dollars to safety net providers. Congress did not intend to alter the definition of DSH-eligible costs or the substantive standards for DSH payments. DSH payment reductions of millions of dollars to safety net providers participating in the Medicaid DSH program under approved payment methodologies by CMS. SEC. 2. REVISION OF MEDICAID DSH AUDITING AND REPORTING REGULATIONS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with States and disproportionate share hospitals, will not enforce changes in policy related to the calculation of limits under the Medicaid DSH program. An interim final rule will be published to revise the Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will publish an interim final rule to revise Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, correcting policy changes and providing guidance for implementation. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will publish an interim final rule to revise Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, correcting policy changes and providing guidance for implementation. The new rule will include regulatory changes allowing hospitals to include all costs related to services provided to uninsured patients, even if the patient has insurance that covers other services. The CMS allows States to use their definition of allowable costs in Medicaid plans for computing costs related to services provided to uninsured patients, as long as the costs do not exceed allowable amounts. CMS allows States to use their definition of allowable costs in Medicaid plans for services to uninsured patients, as long as they do not exceed Medicare principles of cost reimbursement. The audit requirement for hospital services should be interpreted consistently with the term "hospital services" in the Social Security Act. CMS may revise the General DSH Audit as needed. CMS will revise the General DSH Audit Protocol to allow for alternative methodologies in determining actual costs, including trending forward costs from prior years. Additionally, CMS will revise section 455.304(d)(2) of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations, to permit the use of either an overall cost-to-charge ratio or departmental cost-to-charge ratios. The Code of Federal Regulations is being amended to allow alternative methodologies for determining actual costs, including trending forward costs from prior years. Section 1923(j) of the Social Security Act is also being amended to change the year from 2004 to 2008. The term "CMS" refers to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. The Act defines key terms such as CMS, Medicaid DSH auditing and reporting regulations, Medicaid DSH program, and Secretary.
